introduction.p:
Often we are more interested in the sum of a sequence than in the sequence itself. For example, suppose that for 5 years you have made payments of $100 a month into a savings account that pays 12% annual interest compounded monthly. The sequence
p_n = 100(1.01)^n
gives the current value of the payment you made n months ago (plus interest). However, you are probably more interested in the total amount in your savings account, which is the sum of the terms p_n from n=1 to n=60.
The sum of the terms of a sequence is called a series.

note.p: Although the words "sequence" and "series" are often used interchangeably in everyday English, they have different meanings in mathematics. A sequence is a list of numbers, whereas a series is a single number obtained by computing a sum. For example, the list of numbers 2, 4, 8, 16, 32 is a sequence. The sum of those five terms is the series 2+4+8+16+32=62

introduction.p: We use the symbol S_n to denote the sum of the first n terms of a sequence. Thus, for the sequence above, S_5 = 62.

statement.p: Find the series S_6 for the sequence with general term a_n = 3n + 1.

solution.p: The first six terms of the sequence are 4, 7, 10, 13, 16, and 19 Thus, S_6 = 4 + 7 + 10 + 13 + 16 + 19 = 69

statement.p: Find the series S_5 for the sequence with general term b_n = b^2.

subsection.title: Arithmetic Series
subsection.p: We can find a formula for the sum of the first n terms of an arithmetic sequence.

investigation.title: Sum of an Arithmetic Sequence
investigation.p: Consider the sum of the first 12 terms of the sequence with general term a_n = 4n+1. That is, S_{12} = 5 + 9 + 13 + \cdots + 41 + 45 + 49 In mathematics, as in other fields, making discoveries often depends on looking at familiar objects in a new way.

li.p: Let's write the terms of the series in the opposite order: S_{12} = 49 + 45 + 41 + \cdots + 13 + 9 + 5

Now add these two equations term by term, to find \begin{aligned}[t] S_{12} \amp = 5 + 9 + 13 + \cdots + 41 + 45 + 49\\ S_{12} \amp = 49 + 45 + 41 + \cdots + 13 + 9 + 5\\ 2S_{12} \amp = \\ \end{aligned}

Each term of the sum is the same, namely, 54! (Do you see why?) Also, the term 54 occurs 12 times because we are adding 12 terms of the sequence. We have discoverd that 2S_{12} = 12(54) so S_{12} = \dfrac{(\hphantom{0000})(\hphantom{0000})}{(\hphantom{0000})} =
Notice that the number 54 is the sum of the first term of the arithmetic series, 5, and the last term, 49. In other words, 54 = a_1 + a_n. This is the key observation we need to produce our formula.

In general, this sum a_1 + a_n occurs n times and results in twice the series we want. Thus, 2S_n = a_1 + a_n and dividing both sides by 2 gives us the following formula for computing an arithmetic series.

assemblage.title: Arithmetic Series
assemblage.p: The sum S_n of the first n terms of an arithmetic sequence is S_n = \dfrac{n}{2} (a_1 + a_n)

statement.p: Find the sum of the first 15 odd integers.

solution.p: The odd integers form an arithmetic sequence with first term a_1 = 1 and common difference 2. Thus, the general term of the sequence is a_n = 1 + (n - 1)2, and we would like to find the series S_{15}. We begin by finding the last term of the series, a_{15}. a_{15} = 1 + (15-1)2 = 29 Next we use the formula for S_n with n = 15,~a_1 = 1, and a_{15} = 29: S_{15} = \dfrac{15}{2} (1 + 29) = 225

statement.p: Find the sum of the first 100 terms of the sequence 2, 5, 8, 11, \cdots.

Arlene starts a part-time job in a print shop at a salary of $800 per month. If she keeps up with the training program her salary will increase by $35 per month. How much will Arlene have earned at the end of the 18-month training program?

solution.p: Arlene's monthly salary is an arithmetic sequence with a_1 = 800 and d = 35. Thus, the general tern of the sequence is a_n = 800 + (n-1)35, and we would like to find the series S_{18}. We begin by finding the last term of the series, a_{18}. a_{18} = 800 + (18-1)(35) = 1395 Next we use the formula for S_n with n = 18,~ a_1 = 800, and a_{18} = 1395. S_{18} = \dfrac{18}{2} (800 + 1395) = 19,755 Arlene's total earnings for the 18 months will be $19,755.

statement.p: Arlene from the previous example decides to start a savings account. After her first paycheck, she deposits $50, and plans to increase her deposits by $5 per month. How much will she have in the savings account at the end of the 18-month training program?

subsection.title: Geometric Series
subsection.p: We can also find a formula for the sum of the first n terms of a geometric sequence.

investigation.title: Sum of a Geometric Sequrnce
investigation.p: We'll compute the sum of the first 9 terms of the geometric sequence with a=3 and r=3. Its general term is a_n = 3(3)^{n-1}, or 3^n. Then S_9 = 3 + 3^2 + 3^3 + \cdots + 3^9

li.p: Instead of writing the terms in the opposite order, as we did for the arithmetic series, this time we will multiply each term of S_9 by the common ratio, 3. 3 \cdot S_9 = 3 \cdot 3 + 3 \cdot 3^2 + 3 \cdot 3^3 + \cdots + 3 \cdot 3^8 + 3 \cdot 3^9 or 3S_9 = 3^2 + 3^3 + 3^4 + \cdots + 3^9 + 3^{10}

Next we subtract the first equation from the second equation. Most of the terms will cancel out in the subtraction. \begin{aligned}[t] 3S_9 \amp = ~~~~~~~~~~~3^2 + 3^3 + \cdots + 3^9 + 3^{10}\\ -[S_9 \amp = ~~~3 + 3^2 + 3^3 + \cdots + 3^9]\\ 2S_9 \amp = -3 ~ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ + 3^{10}\\ \end{aligned}
Notice that the second term of the numerator is a_1 (3 in this example) and the first term is a_{10}~ (3 \cdot 3^9 or 3^{10}).
Although you might not guess it from this example, the denominator of the expression, 2, is equal to r-1. In general, we can derive the following formula for computing a geometric series.

assemblage.title: Geometric Series
assemblage.p: The sum S_n of the first n terms of a geometric sequence is S_n = \dfrac{a_{n+1} - a_1}{r-1}

statement.p: Find the sum of the first five terms of the sequence 5, \dfrac{10}{3}, \dfrac{20}{9}, \dfrac{40}{27}, \cdots.
Find the sum of the first ten terms of the geometric sequence 100,~ 110,~ 121,~ \cdots.

Payam's starting salary as an engineer is $60,000 with a 5% annual raise for each of the next five years, depending on suitable progress. If Payam receives each salary increase, how much will he make over the next six years?

solution.p: Payam's salary is multiplied each year by a factor of 1.05, so its values form a geometric sequence with a common ratio of r=1.05. The general term of the sequence is a_n = 60,000(1.05)^{n-1}. His total income over the six years will be the sum of the first six terms of the sequence. Thus, \begin{aligned}[t] S_6 \amp = \dfrac{a_7 - a_1}{r-1} = \dfrac{60,000(1.05)^6 - 60,000}{1.05-1}\\ \amp = 408,114.77 \\ \end{aligned} Payam will earn $408,114.77 over the next six years.
